fields.Title of Contribution: Leveraging Today’s Entrepreneurship Program Into Building Tomorrow’s Ecosystem-Arizona State
fields.Description/Abstract: Entrepreneurial ecosystems have emerged as a focal point in the strategic agendas of national and regional governmental bodies, driven by the goal of stimulating economic growth. The overarching objective of these ecosystems is to act as a facilitative milieu for high-growth ventures. Within the United States, there exists a pronounced emphasis on advancing entrepreneurial initiatives in the domains of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), as these ventures are more likely to result in companies that grow beyond their entrepreneur (Schumpeter, 1934). Universities, in concert with governmental support structures, occupy a pivotal role in the orchestration and evolution of EEs. Noteworthy in this regard is the proactive involvement of the National Science Foundation (NSF), which has championed a program specifically designed to support nascent entrepreneurs.<br><br>This session will be of interest to any faculty member involved with innovation, entrepreneurs, or entrepreneurship. As academics, we don’t always have the time to reflect on our role and place within the larger environment. This session will give participants the opportunity to share with and learn from their peers. This session will introduce and discuss the entrepreneur ecosystem framework and then use examples to illustrate its application, which will also include the I-Corps training program and its training outcomes. I-Corps is an NSF-funded program aimed at supporting University-led innovation commercialization. Results from I-Corps-supported research will be discussed, and two (or more) members of the national I-Corps program will discuss their experiences.
